about_section.title: The Mandate of Heaven
about_section.description: The Jade Emperor maintains balance in the cosmos, overseeing the gods and ensuring divine order.

about_section.title: Mythological Power & Influence
about_section.description: As the supreme ruler, he presides over all deities and dictates the fate of mortals and spirits alike.

about_section.title: Worship & Cultural Impact
about_section.description: Honored in Taoist temples, the Jade Emperor is revered during the Lunar New Year as the divine judge of human deeds.

about_section.title: Allies & Rivalries
about_section.description: He commands the celestial army and has Sun Wukong and Guanyin as allies, yet faces challenges from demons and ambitious gods.

about_section.title: Artifacts & Symbols of Power
about_section.description: The **Mandate of Heaven** grants him the divine right to rule, and his **Golden Robe** symbolizes cosmic authority.

about_section.title: Mortal Encounters & Legacy
about_section.description: Legends say he rewards the virtuous and punishes the wicked, influencing the concept of righteous rulership in Chinese history.

legends: ğŸ“œ The Birth of the Jade Emperor: Once a mortal prince, he ascended through trials of wisdom and virtue to become the supreme ruler.
âš– The Judgment of Souls: He assigns divine bureaucrats to maintain cosmic balance and oversee human fate.
ğŸŒŸ The War in Heaven: Led the celestial army to defeat the rebel demon king, ensuring order in the heavens.
ğŸ‡ The Lunar New Year Blessing: Every year, he evaluates mortal deeds and bestows fortune accordingly.

ğŸŒŸ The Celestial Palace: His grand divine court where all gods report and await his command.

about_section.title: The Birth of the Universe
about_section.description: Pangu emerged from the Cosmic Egg and separated Yin and Yang, forming the heavens and the earth.

about_section.title: Mythological Power & Influence
about_section.description: With each movement, Pangu shaped mountains, rivers, and the sky, bringing structure to the cosmos.

about_section.title: Worship & Cultural Impact
about_section.description: Though not worshiped in a traditional sense, Pangu is a foundational figure in Chinese cosmology, symbolizing creation and balance.

about_section.title: Artifacts & Symbols of Power
about_section.description: His **Cosmic Axe** was used to divide heaven and earth, while his breath, sweat, and body became the elements of nature.

about_section.title: Mortal Encounters & Legacy
about_section.description: Pangu's legend serves as the starting point of Chinese mythology, influencing later deities and cosmological beliefs.

legends: ğŸ”¨ The Shaping of the World: Pangu spent 18,000 years holding up the sky until it was stable.
ğŸŒ The Transformation of Pangu: Upon his death, his body became mountains, rivers, and the sky, ensuring the world's existence.
lore: ğŸª“ The Cosmic Axe: The tool that separated Yin from Yang and shaped the world.
ğŸ” The Five Sacred Mountains: Formed from Panguâ€™s limbs, they represent the five directions and cosmic balance.

about_section.title: The Creation of Humanity
about_section.description: Nuwa molded the first humans from clay, breathing life into them and guiding their growth.

about_section.title: Mythological Power & Influence
about_section.description: As the divine weaver, she mended the broken sky with five-colored stones, saving the world from ruin.

about_section.title: Worship & Cultural Impact
about_section.description: Revered as the mother of humanity, Nuwa is honored in temples and ancestral rituals throughout China.

about_section.title: Allies & Rivalries
about_section.description: She stands beside Fuxi as a creator, yet she opposes chaos and destruction that threaten humanity.

about_section.title: Artifacts & Symbols of Power
about_section.description: The **Clay of Creation** shaped life, while the **Five-Colored Stones** restored balance to the heavens.

about_section.title: Mortal Encounters & Legacy
about_section.description: Legends say that Nuwaâ€™s divine act of repairing the sky ensures the stability of the world to this day.

legends: ğŸŒ The Creation of Humanity: Nuwa formed the first people from clay, ensuring their survival and reproduction.
ğŸŒˆ The Weaving of the Sky: When the heavens shattered, she gathered five-colored stones to repair the celestial dome.
ğŸ”¥ The Battle Against Chaos: She stood against forces of destruction, ensuring the stability of the world.
ğŸ’ The Bond with Fuxi: Together, she and Fuxi established order and divine teachings for humanity.

ğŸŒˆ The Five-Colored Stones: Magical artifacts that sealed the broken sky.

name: Sun Wukong
title: The Monkey King, Defier of Heaven

about_section.title: The Birth of the Monkey King
about_section.description: Born from a mystical stone atop Flower-Fruit Mountain, Sun Wukong gained intelligence and supernatural abilities.

about_section.title: Mythological Power & Influence
about_section.description: He mastered transformation magic, strength beyond measure, and immortality through divine trickery.

about_section.title: Worship & Cultural Impact
about_section.description: Revered as a symbol of rebellion and perseverance, his legend endures in Chinese folklore, literature, and theater.

about_section.title: Allies & Rivalries
about_section.description: Once a celestial rebel, he was ultimately subdued by Buddha and later redeemed as a disciple of Tang Sanzang.

about_section.title: Artifacts & Symbols of Power
about_section.description: His **Ruyi Jingu Bang** is a magical staff capable of growing or shrinking at will, while the **Cloud Somersault** grants him flight.

about_section.title: Mortal Encounters & Legacy
about_section.description: Sun Wukong represents the undying spirit of defiance, intelligence, and adventure, influencing countless heroic figures in Chinese storytelling.

legends: âš¡ The Havoc in Heaven: Sun Wukong declared himself â€˜The Great Sage Equal to Heavenâ€™ and waged war against the celestial army.
ğŸ‘ The Theft of Immortal Peaches: He sneaked into Heavenâ€™s garden and consumed the divine peaches of immortality.
ğŸ›• The Five Finger Mountain: After defying Heaven, he was sealed under a mountain by Buddha for 500 years.
ğŸ›¤ The Journey to the West: Under Tang Sanzangâ€™s guidance, he embarked on a sacred pilgrimage to atone for his past misdeeds.

sacred_places: ğŸ¹ The Palace of the Archer God

about_section.title: The Trial of the Ten Suns
about_section.description: When ten sun-birds scorched the earth, Hou Yi took his legendary bow and shot down nine of them to save humanity.

about_section.title: Mythological Power & Influence
about_section.description: Gifted by the heavens, his skill in archery was unmatched, and his name became synonymous with heroism and balance.

about_section.title: Worship & Cultural Impact
about_section.description: Hou Yi is revered in Chinese folklore as a symbol of sacrifice, justice, and righteous power, often depicted in art and storytelling.

about_section.title: Allies & Rivalries
about_section.description: His love for Changâ€™e defined his legend, yet his rivalry with jealous deities and fate itself led to his tragic downfall.

about_section.title: Artifacts & Symbols of Power
about_section.description: The **Celestial Bow** was said to have been forged by the gods, and the **Sun-Slaying Arrows** carried divine power.

about_section.title: Mortal Encounters & Legacy
about_section.description: Legends say his great deeds earned him divine recognition, yet he ultimately lost immortality and was separated from his beloved Changâ€™e.

legends: ğŸ”¥ The Slaying of the Nine Suns: Hou Yi saved the world by shooting down nine of the ten celestial suns that were burning the earth.
